summary: This document is a chain of emails from September 2019 between a U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) prosecutor and Jeffrey Goldberg, an Amazon.com attorney, regarding a grand jury subpoena (CRIM1031692) issued to Amazon. The emails discuss scheduling calls and Amazon's legal position, citing First Amendment concerns about producing records related to customer purchases of 'expressive materials' (e.g., books, videos) in connection with an investigation, which is confirmed to involve the deceased Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Goldberg
persons.role: Associate General Counsel, Litigation & Regulatory at Amazon.com LLC
persons.context: Amazon's attorney corresponding with federal prosecutors regarding a grand jury subpoena for customer records. He cites First Amendment case law to argue for a heightened legal standard before compelling production of records related to 'expressive materials'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'Mr. Epstein' in an email. His death is mentioned as a factor Amazon is considering in evaluating whether First Amendment privacy concerns are still active regarding the subpoena for records.

connections.description: Goldberg, as Amazon's attorney, is corresponding with prosecutors about a subpoena for records related to an investigation involving Epstein. He is evaluating legal obligations and privacy concerns related to Epstein's accounts or addresses.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Mentioned in an email as a factor Amazon's legal team is considering when evaluating the ongoing necessity and privacy implications of the grand jury subpoena for records.

events.title: Email negotiations regarding Subpoena CRIM1031692
events.description: Series of emails between a U.S. Attorney's Office and Amazon attorney Jeffrey Goldberg scheduling calls and discussing legal arguments about complying with a grand jury subpoena for Amazon customer records related to the Epstein investigation.

locations: Seattle, WA 98121 (Amazon corporate office location mentioned in Goldberg's signature)
Western District of Washington (venue for cited case Amazon.com LLC v. Lay)
District of Columbia (venue for several cited grand jury cases)
keyFacts: A federal grand jury subpoena (CRIM1031692) was issued to Amazon.com as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

Amazon's legal counsel, Jeffrey Goldberg, raised First Amendment concerns, arguing that records of customer purchases of 'expressive materials' (books, videos) require a heightened showing of relevance, need, and exhaustion of other avenues before being compelled.
The subpoena sought records for accounts that shipped to or were billed in connection with specific addresses, which the prosecutor indicated were linked to the Epstein investigation.
Goldberg referenced Epstein's death as a factor potentially affecting the evaluation of whether customer privacy interests in the sought records remained active.
Amazon indicated a willingness to file a motion to quash the subpoena if the prosecutors decided to continue pursuing the records, preferring a stipulated briefing schedule.
